title: Thoughts about logo (mycorp)
author: mycorp

comments.content:
The inner circle of the O in «CORP» seems off center. It might be in the center, but with the missing line to the «R» it looks odd.  
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_  
Fischers Fritz fischt frische Fische, frische Fische fischt Fischers Fritz.

Do you suggest to move the cirle to the right?  
I confirmed, and it is centered.

Yep or pull it slightly bigger to the right.  
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_  
Fischers Fritz fischt frische Fische, frische Fische fischt Fischers Fritz.

I pulled it slightly to the right, here.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071119051255im_/http:/typophile.com/files/mycorp-logo-20070913-01_5428.png)

And here I made it a little bit wider, to the right, so its center is not really centered anymore.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071119051255im_/http:/typophile.com/files/mycorp-logo-20070913-02_6643.png)

What do you think?

The first one looks pretty good. The O is more balanced in it. I’m not a big fan of that «d» you used in «design», it gets to much attention. Overall I think you are pretty close to the end. What do you think?  
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_  
Fischers Fritz fischt frische Fische, frische Fische fischt Fischers Fritz.

I hope I am close to the end! :)  
I’ll have a look at that d, i don’t like it too much either.  
I’ll post another one soon.  
Thanks!

Here is a new try.  
I tried to put the bottom text in caps. What do you think of it this way?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071119051255im_/http:/typophile.com/files/mycorp-logo-20070913-02_4676.png)

Much better! I like the composition of professional and clean versus hand made. Give the tagline some more space between CORP, let it breath.  
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_  
Fischers Fritz fischt frische Fische, frische Fische fischt Fischers Fritz.

Like this?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071119051255im_/http:/typophile.com/files/mycorp-logo-20070913-03_6038.png)

I would use the space from the inner circle of the O, to have similar proportions. Horizontal or vertical.  
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_  
Fischers Fritz fischt frische Fische, frische Fische fischt Fischers Fritz.
What do you mean?

Sorry for my bad english! I mean this :)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071119051255im_/http:/typophile.com/files/test_4512.jpg)

\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_  
Fischers Fritz fischt frische Fische, frische Fische fischt Fischers Fritz

Ok, here is one with the vertical space and one with the horizontal one.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071119051255im_/http:/typophile.com/files/mycorp-logo-20070913-04_4058.png)
  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071119051255im_/http:/typophile.com/files/mycorp-logo-20070913-05_5631.png)

The latter is better — actually, I would put the tag line even closer. I’d say the vertical stroke width of “CORP” — the width of the stem of “P”, that is — might be the ideal distance.

The font for the tag line needs to be significantly thicker.

Thicker tagline, closer to CORP.  
(Did you mean even closer?)  
Thanks a lot for your help guys.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071119051255im_/http:/typophile.com/files/mycorp-logo-20070913-06_3952.png)
Both the “R” sign and the tag line are still too far to the right — they should \*optically\* right-align with the “P” which they aren’t right now.
So, the tagline is also a bit too much to the left, I guess I will have to reduce its size :)

Ok, here it goes.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071119051255im_/http:/typophile.com/files/mycorp-logo-20070913-07_5754.png)

OK, I see you want the tag line not only right-align with “CORP”, but left-align with it too. I’m not sure that’s good.

Because right now, there is an optical disconnect betwenn “my” and the rest — the same problem your original design had. Your boss rejected the overlapping, that’s unfortunate, but you still need \*some\* kind of connection.

Idea 1: Let the tag line grow to the left so it goes under the “y” in “my”.

Idea 2: Put the tag line in red, same as “my”.

Neither of the two is really brilliant, but still worth a try.

Here is the one with the tagline in red.  
Personally I don’t like it that much. What do you think?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071119051255im_/http:/typophile.com/files/mycorp-logo-20070914-01_5162.png)

I tried your first idea, but I can’t make the tagline fit well because of the y’s tail.  
What if I shrink a bit the tagline, so it doesn’t left-align with CORP, but only right-align? Still, it may not hold the ’my’ more than before.

Here’s an example:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071119051255im_/http:/typophile.com/files/mycorp-logo-20070914-02_6482.png)

You are aligning your strapline mechanically rather than by eye, it needs to move left a touch, but before you do that postion the logo on a letterhead and business card check that it will be large enough, my impression is that it might be too light/small; while you are looking at that check the weight of the left vertical of the y; there are some kerning issues in comunicação, especially in ação which need tightening; the ® is floating rather than seeming connected to CORP.

Tim

I don’t know what you mean when you said, “I can’t make the tagline fit well because of the y’s tail.” The point is to have the line start right next to the tail.

And no, the red tag line really doesn’t work at all.

Have you looked at this at a small size (say, 1” wide) ? I think some of those lines and connections are going to get awfully small and hard to see. The counter formed by the outline between the R and P is going to close in and appear black.

Also, looking at it in a smaller size – try 2” wide – will give you a better idea of how the tagline should look. I think your current setting will be too small.

I’ve been in the back and just reading this thread for some time. But I guess I have to comment now.

I 150% agree with jonsel about size problems. You are going to have them anyway you look at your logo. If you want to use it at small sizes you’ll have to drop the outlines and use bigger tagline.

But since this should be a design and PR company I would say that if I had something to design, I wouldn’t give it to this company because even their logo isn’t smart designed.

To my opinion “my” and “corp” don’t connect at all. You have somehow “my” as a symbol of the logo, but then you are playing with “corp”. I don’t like this logo at all and I don’t think it will become a decent logo anyway.

I’m really sorry but I thought I may be too late if I stay quiet. And I’m sorry if I’m the bearer of the bad news. I just wanted to be frank with you.

Thank you all for your comments and your help.  
I know this logo is not that good, but I need a logo for the company within 2 weeks or so.  
I’m not a designer myself, but I’m the one who has to do this work for now. Meanwhile we will have some decent logo designed, but for now I just would like something that doesn’t look like complete crap.

Thanks for your suggestions. I will try to find a way to make this a little better.

I find it incredible that a design and PR agency would sacrifice its own identity for the sake of speed. Two weeks is more than adequate time to develop a good logo.

Sometimes the hardest decision to make for a designer (or anyone designing something) is to kill what they are working on. However, all the time spent on noodling this particular direction could be much better spent on finding something better. And by better, I’m not suggesting you need to invent a new typeface or re-invent the graphic wheel. Many design firms both huge and tiny use a very well set typeface with little modification. If you need a crisp, professional appearance, and you need it quick, that is the best way to go.

Like Litera, I hate to sound harsh and overly critical, but sometimes we need a creative director to straighten us out. I’ve had it done to me, and have had to do similar to others before. Please realize it’s not about you personally, but an honest attempt to help you get the best results for your agency.

Jonsel, I appreciate all comments, even the ones who tells me bad news.  
I really want to make this work well, and my goal is not to get just some identity, but an identity that really works.

The company is having some trouble because of one of its founders (the designer) who was supposed to do some work, but he abandoned the company in the middle of its creation. I’m not a designer, I work in the commercial and administrative area, but since I’m alone and I really think this can be a successful company, I don’t want to abandon it as well.

I need some kind of logo just for bureaucratic stuff, to have the company registered and so. Then I will have to find a decent solution for the identity of MyCorp.

I really thank you and everyone for all critiques, and specially for being honest and telling me what you really think.
